Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Fluorescence Activated Cell Sorter (FACS)

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal is for the acquisition of a state-of-the-art Fluorescence Activated Cell Sorter (FACS) that will become part of a flow cytometry/cell sorting shared use facility appealing to a diverse set of research programs on the University of Oklahoma (OU) campus in Norman. Cell sorting is recognized as important and indispensable tools in fields ranging from basic biology in the life sciences to translational biomedical engineering research. Acquisition of state-of-the-art cell sorting capabilities on the OU-Norman campus would not only make available needed resources, but would also provide a powerful complement to existing cellular characterization facilities on the OU-Norman Campus: Scanning Electron Microscopy, Multi-photon Laser Scanning Confocal Microscopy, and Atomic Force Microscopy. Combining detailed information about individual cell structures provided by these microscopy techniques with (i) the extensive statistical information about cell populations from high throughput flow cytometry and (ii) the ability to identify and sort cells from complex populations by immunophenotyping will foster new and innovative research directions across the OU campus.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The cutting-edge biomedical and fundamental biology research that is being performed at the University of Oklahoma Norman in the areas of plant biology, microbiology, drug and gene delivery, biomaterials, tissue engineering, and neuroscience, research that is funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) has received a major boost by the acquisition of the BD FACS-ARIA cell sorting flow cytometer. Cell sorting was critical in several of the experiments planned at the Norman campus and the absence of such an instrument in the campus was compromising several projects forcing researchers to find alternative experiments that where not as efficient as the ones conducting using a cell sorter. The state-of-the-art multi-color Fluorescence Activated Cell Sorter (FACS) improved the research and educational activities in the Life Sciences and Biomedical Engineering at OU.Areas that benefited from the acquisition of the instrument include:

1.  Development of novel non-viral gene carriers for gene therapy.

2. Isolation and characterization of stem cells for Tissue Engineered Bone Tendons.

3. New insights into the energy conservation pathways in marine bacteria.

4. New insights into global carbon and nitrogen cycles through discoveries in the physiology of nutrient uptake in algae.

5. Investigations into synapses and neural circuitry in Drosophila as models of human neurological disorders.

6. Development of novel targeted approaches in cancer therapy.

7. New insights in the cardiovascular biology of endothelial cell during exersise.

The new equipment has specific benefits and impact for OU:

(1) it provides the needed state of the art research tools needed by OU faculty to be competitive in federal funding;

(2) it promotes collaborative interaction among the participating faculty;

(3) it provides graduate student (and in the near future undergraduate student too) training on cutting-edge research equipment.

Furthermore the research has broad impacts due to the fact that the newly acquired equipment has found applications in the fields of fundamental cell biology, cardiovascular disease, biomaterials, and tissue engineering. The educational activities that we have planned also have broad impacts. The outreach to middle school teachers will provide opportunities for exposure of hundreds of students to cutting edge research and the wonders of science. Likewise the summer camp outreach activities to underrepresented groups, and course offerings will expose high school, undergraduate, and graduate students to cutting edge research techniques of flow cytometry and cell sorting. Already the flow cytometry core facility is promoting “interdisciplinary interactions between students in the life sciences and engineering and has allowed the involvement in the maintenance and operation of the instrument to graduate students in the Biomedical Engineering field of Under-represented minorities.
